title-group.article-title: Impact of Smoking and Smoking Cessation on Arterial Stiffness in Healthy Participants

article-meta.aff: 1Chinese PLA Postgraduate Medical School, Beijing, China
2Department of Cardiology, General Hospital of Chinese People's Armed Police Forces, Beijing, China
3Medical Examination Center, General Hospital of Chinese People's Armed Police Forces, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: Liu Hui-Liang, Department of Cardiology, General Hospital of Chinese People's Armed Police Forces, Beijing 100039, China. Email: lhl518@vip.sina.com

abstract.p: Smoking is associated with increased arterial stiffness. However, the impact of smoking cessation on arterial stiffness remains unknown. We investigated the effect of smoking cessation on arterial stiffness. Healthy participants (n = 209) were divided into nonsmoking (NSm, n = 96), quit smoking (QSm, n = 61), and maintained smoking groups (MSm, n = 52). Arterial stiffness indexes (ankle–brachial index [ABI] and brachial–ankle pulse wave velocity [baPWV]) were assessed at baseline, and after 6 and 12 months. Baseline, arterial stiffness was significantly higher in the MSm and QSm groups than in the NSm group (P < .001). In the QSm group, there was significant difference in ABI between baseline and 12 months (P = .03). No significant differences were shown in baPWV. Both ABI and baPWV were similar between QSm and MSm group at 12 months. However, there was significant difference between QSm and NSm groups (P < .001). This study shows that 12 months of smoking cessation is associated with improved arterial stiffness.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cigarette smoking is one of the important preventable causes of cardiovascular disease (CVD) that has been associated with increased stiffness of large arteries, an independent predictor of CVD. 1,2 Pulse wave velocity (PWV) is a representative measure of arterial stiffness and has been used as a marker of vascular damage as well as CVD risk. 1,3 The majority of studies have confirmed that chronic smoking is associated with increasing arterial stiffness. However, whether arterial stiffness is reversed after smoking cessation and the time at which this may occur remains unknown. 4 Therefore, we studied the effects of smoking and smoking cessation for 6 and 12 months on aortic stiffness in healthy participants.

sec.title: Participants and Protocol
sec.p: A total of 480 participants were recruited in our study between September and December 2009 from the physical examination in our hospital. Inclusion criteria were 18 years to ≤ 65 years; healthy males. Exclusion criteria were systemic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, peripheral arterial disease (PAD) or cardiac disease or taking any medication. The smoking habits and fitness levels were assessed from a questionnaire. Current smokers (n = 113) were defined as those who smoked 1 cigarette or more per day for at least 1 year. Nonsmokers (NSm, n = 96) were defined as those who had never smoked. Current smokers were divided into 2 subgroups according to whether they intended to quit smoking. One group (quit smoking [QSm], n = 61) was ex-smokers, another group (maintained smoking [MSm], n = 52). Participants who wanted to stop smoking were provided pharmacologic (nicotine-replacement products were excluded) and non-pharmacologic therapy to assist patients to quit. Pharmacologic therapy included varenicline administered 0.5 mg/d for 3 days, 0.5 mg twice daily for 4 days, then 1 mg twice daily thereafter and bupropion SR 150 mg/d for 3 days, then 150 mg twice per day through week 12. Non-pharmacologic therapy included psychological counseling and behavioral intervention. Quitting smoking was confirmed by questionnaires and breath carbon monoxide (CO) < 10 ppm. Routine clinical parameters such as body weight, height, age, blood pressure (BP), basic biochemical index including fasting glucose, serum lipids were recorded. Brachial–ankle pulse wave velocity (baPWV) and ankle–brachial index (ABI) were checked in all participants at baseline, and after 6 and 12 months.
The study protocol was approved by local ethics committee and written informed consent was obtained from each participant before investigation.

sec.title: BaPWV and ABI Measurements
sec.p: Both baPWV and ABI were examined by VP-1000 (Colin Co., Komaki, Japan) automatic device. Two indices, baPWV and ABI, were obtained using a volume-plethysmographic apparatus by simultaneous BP and waveform measurements on all 4 limbs along with electrocardiogram (ECG) and phonogram tracings. Decreases in ABI and increases in baPWV resulted in more arterial stiffness. The PWV was automatically calculated by time-phasic analysis using the following formula: distance between 2 sites divided by pulse wave transit time. The baPWV was measured from the ascending point of right brachial pulse volume recorder to the ascending point of each ankle pulse volume recorder. The distance between the right brachium and ankle was estimated based on body height and derived from statistical studies. 5,6

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Continuous data were expressed as mean ± standard deviation. The characteristics of the 3 groups were analyzed by 1-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). The changes and differences in baPWV and ABI at baseline, 6, and 12 months were analyzed by 1-way ANOVA and repeated-measures ANOVA. If the data failed the normality test, a nonparametric analysis was used. The data of within groups were analyzed by Student-Newman-Keuls q tests. All tests were 2-tailed and the significance was set at P < .05. All tests were performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS 13.0) software. Analyses were undertaken on an intention-to-treat basis and per protocol.

sec.title: Patient Characteristics
sec.p: The 209 healthy male participants were aged 22 to 65 years (43.6 ± 8.7; mean ± SD). The current smokers smoked on average 13 cigarettes/d for 3 to 43 years. Of 113 smokers, 61 were motivated to stop smoking. At the end of the sixth month, 6 smokers reduced smoking but failed to quit, 6 relapsed, and 2 lost to follow-up. At the end of 12th month, 4 relapsed and 2 were lost to follow-up. The remaining 41 participants continued abstinence (CO confirmed) and completed the study. After 12 months of follow-up, 52 smokers rejected stopping smoking, 9 were lost to follow-up. Of the 96 nonsmokers, 18 were lost to follow-up. The participant flowchart is shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Consort statement and flow diagram. Of the 480 eligible patients, 209 were included. Finally, 78 of 96 nonsmokers were analyzed and 41 in QSm group and 43 in MSm group. QSm indicates quit smoking; MSm, maintained smoking.

sec.p: The changes in the participants’ characteristics among the 3 groups during the follow-up period are shown in Table 1. Among the 3 groups, the NSm group had the highest body mass index (BMI) values compared with the MSm group (26.70 ± 3.16 vs 25.6 ± 3.15, P = .03) and QSm group (26.70 ± 3.16 vs 26.28 ± 2.98, P = .25) at baseline. There was no significant difference in age, BP, fasting glucose, serum lipid, and heart rate at the 3 time points among the 3 groups. Although there was a trend for increase in weight in QSm participants, the difference was not significant among the 3 time points. All of the participants did not take the known medicine affecting arterial stiffness during the follow-up.

caption.p: The Participants’ Characteristics Among 3 Groups During the Follow-Up Period.a

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; HDL, high-density lipoprotein; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; NSm, nonsmokers; MSm, maintain smokers; QSm, ex-smokers; M, month; SD, standard deviation.
aData are presented as mean ± SD or median (interquartile range).

sec.title: Arterial stiffness parameters among the 3 groups at baseline
sec.p: Compared with the NSm group, ABI was significantly lower in both MSm group and QSm group (1.26 [1.15-1.28] vs 1.05 [1.04-1.07] vs 1.04 [1.02-1.06], P < .001). However, the baPWV were significantly higher in both MSm group and QSm group (1303 [1288-1307] vs 1508 [1467-1522] vs 1511 [1460-1529], P < .001).

sec.title: Changes in arterial stiffness indexes among the 3 groups after 12 months of follow-up
sec.p: The changes and differences in baPWV and ABI among baseline, 6th, and 12th month are shown in Figures 2 and 3.

caption.p: The change in baPWV among the 3 groups at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Data are presented as median (interquartile range). *P < .001vs NSm group. baPWV indicates brachial-ankle pulse wave velocity; NSm, nonsmoking.

The change in ABI among the 3 groups at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Data are presented as median(interquartile range). *P < .001vs NSm group, †P < .05 VS baseline. ABI indicates ankle-brachial index; NSm, nonsmoking.

sec.p: After 6 months of follow-up, there was no significant difference in ABI between MSm group and QSm group (1.05 [1.04-1.07] vs 1.06 [1.04-1.08], P = .623), while significant difference was observed between NSm group and MSm group, as well as NSm group and QSm group (1.26 [1.15-1.28] vs 1.05 [1.04-1.07] vs 1.06 [1.04-1.08], P < .001). The same results were obtained after 12 months of follow-up (1.27 [1.16-1.29] vs 1.07 [1.06-1.09] vs 1.04 [1.02-1.06], P < .001).

After 6 months of follow-up, there was no significant difference in baPWV between MSm group and QSm group (1517 [1465-1529] vs 1502 [1458-1519], P = .696), while significant difference was observed between NSm group and MSm group and between NSm group and QSm group (1312 [1306-1323] vs 1517 [1489-1529] vs 1502 [1458-1519], P < .001). The same results were obtained after 12 months of follow-up (1325 [1312-1330] vs 1525 [1514-1530] vs 1497 [1403-1500], P < .001).

sec.title: Changes in arterial stiffness indexes at baseline, 6 months, 12 months of follow-up in each group
sec.p: In the NSm group and MSm group, no significant differences between baseline and 12th month were observed in arterial stiffness parameters.

In QSm group, no significant differences were observed in ABI comparing baseline with the 6th month (1.04 [1.02-1.06] vs 1.06 [1.04-1.08], P = .479) and comparing 6th month with the 12th month (1.06 [1.04-1.08] vs 1.07 [1.06-1.09], P = .643). However, there was a significant difference in ABI between baseline and 12th month (1.04 [1.02-1.06] vs 1.07 [1.06-1.09], P = .030).

In the QSm group, there was no significant difference in baPWV between baseline and 6th month (1511 [1460-1529] vs 1502 [1458-1519], P = .438); no significant difference in baPWV between the 6th month and 12th month (1502 [1458-1519] vs 1497 [1403-1500], P = .366); no significant difference in baPWV between the baseline and 12th month (1511 [1460-1529] vs 1497 [1403-1500], P = .283), although the baPWV was lowest at 12th month.

The results of intention-to-treat analysis were similar to the results of per-protocol analysis. In the QSm group, the result showed that there was still significant difference in ABI between baseline and 12th month (1.04 [1.02-1.07] vs 1.06 [1.04-1.09], P = .039). Arterial stiffness parameters among the 3 groups during the follow-up period are shown in Table 2.

caption.p: Arterial Stiffness Parameters Among 3 Groups During the Follow-Up Period.

fn.p: Abbreviations: ABI, ankle–brachial Index; baPWV, brachial–ankle pulse wave velocity; NSm, nonsmokers; MSm, maintain smokers; QSm, ex-smokers; M, month.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of this study indicated that the ABI was lower and the baPWV was higher in current smokers than in nonsmokers. These findings confirm that chronic cigarette smoking acutely increases arterial stiffness. Smoking is thought to be involved in the initiation and progression of atherosclerosis via several different mechanisms. 7 –9 Arterial stiffness may be one of the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms. Arterial stiffness is increasingly being recognized as an important cardiovascular risk factor and an independent predictor of all-cause and cardiovascular death. 10 –12 There is evidence showing that compliance of both large- and medium-sized arteries decreases immediately after smoking 1 cigarette. 13 –15 Our results are consistent with previous findings that the annual ratio of change in the baPWV during the study period was significantly greater in the continuous heavy smokers (11.0 ± 1.9 cm/s per year) than the never smokers (5.5 ± 0.6 cm/s per year). This difference remained significant even after adjustments for covariates, including age (P < .05). 16 Lee et al 17 have reported that compared with never smokers, former and current smokers had significantly smaller mean ABI in the unadjusted, age-adjusted, and multivariate-adjusted models (P < .001 in all models). Several studies have demonstrated that acute smoking and chronic smoking impair regional arterial distensibility and increases PWV. 16,18,19

There are adequate evidences suggesting that smoking cessation is an important way to improve cardiovascular risk, and it may favorably affect primary and secondary prevention of CVD and decrease cardiovascular mortality. 20,21 Several studies show that smoking cessation can improve arterial stiffness. 22 –24 It remains unknown, however, what length of smoking cessation period is required for such an improvement. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to prospectively observe the effect of smoking cessation for 6 and 12 months on arterial stiffness separately. Our results show that the ABI of smoking cessation at 6th month and 12th month had an increasing trend and the baPWV had a decreasing trend compared with baseline, although there is no significant difference in contrast with the group that maintained smoking habits. We also carried out an intention-to-treat analysis; similar results were obtained. This means that after quitting smoking for 1 year could improve large artery properties, although arterial stiffness was not reversed. A cross-sectional study shows that arterial stiffness in ex-smokers of >10 years of duration was not significantly different to that of never smokers. That is to say it may take more than a decade to reverse these vascular changes and smoking cessation may help reduce cardiovascular events through amelioration in arterial stiffening. Our findings are in accordance with the data from another prospective study that after 6 months only those patients who quit smoking had a significant reduction in both systemic augmentation index (Aix) and augmentation pressure, an increase in aortic pulse transit time and a tendency toward reduction in PWV. 22 The mechanisms by which smoking cessation may improve arterial stiffness may include amelioration of lipid-solube smoke particles, 25 smoking-induced endothelial dysfunction, 26 vascular tree inflammation, 27 and nicotine-dependent microvascular dysfunction, 28 whereas reduction in inflammatory markers and endothelium dysfunction has been reported after smoking cessation. 26,29 In addition, our study found a nonstatistically significant trend that the change in the ABI and the baPWV was more obvious at the first 6 months than the second 6 months. The precise explanation for this apparent discrepancy remains unknown. The reason might be related to the sharper amelioration of lipid-solube smoke particles, endothelial dysfunction, or reduction in levels of inflammatory markers at the first 6 months.

There are several study limitations in the present study that should be emphasized. First, the number of smoking cessation participants was relatively small. Second, the follow-up time was relatively short. In this study, we failed to observe the time when reversion to arterial stiffness occurs after smoking cessation with 1 year follow-up. Therefore, the stiffening vascular process occurred from smoking, and its reversibility by smoking cessation needs long-term follow-up to further study, so reliable evidences can be used by physicians to convince patients to stop smoking. In addition, after this study a small sample got the motivation to quit smoking. It suggests that the Chinese consciousness should be elevated. The effective control of smoking preventable risk factors through individual effort and policy intervention will greatly reduce the occurrence of CVD in China in the future.

In conclusion, the present study demonstrated that cigarette smoking might increase arterial stiffness and confirmed that smoking cessation for 12 months reduced baPWV and increased ABI, thereby improving arterial stiffness.
